info.document:
By Louis Casiano Jr. | lcasiano@scng.com | Orange County Register

Citing a change in use at the Jack Hammett Sports Complex, an initiative to install artificial turf on two of its fields will be scrapped, and the City of Costa Mesa will negotiate with the Newport-Mesa Unified School District for possible improvements to sports fields at two elementary schools to increase the number of playable hours.

The Costa Mesa City Council on Tuesday, Sept. 5, agreed 4-0 to reduce upgrades to the sports complex to an expansion of the parking lot, creating permanent storage facilities, the construction of walkways to comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act, and restroom upgrades.

Mayor Katrina Foley recused herself from the vote, citing the proximity of the complex to her home.

Councilman Jim Righeimer, a longtime supporter of youth sports programs in the city, praised the parents at the meeting, many of whom stayed until 11:30 p.m. to discuss the matter.

"Everywhere I go, whether it's baseball, soccer, basketball, the moms and the dads that are out there just donating their time are absolutely phenomenal," Righeimer said.

The change of plans for the sports complex stems from the Los Angeles Chargers use of the 14.5-acre facility during the summer months for its preseason training camp, meaning the turf fields would not be used, said Raja Sethuraman, director of public services for the city.

The sports complex is primarily used by the local AYSO groups, flag football teams and other youth sports clubs.

Other plans call for the city to partner with the Newport-Mesa Unified School District to implement improvements to fields at Kaiser Elementary School and Davis Magnet School.

At Kaiser, permanent lighting would be installed at two multi-use sports fields, along with improvements to two baseball fields, ADA improvements and parking lot upgrades.

A track field at Davis Magnet School would receive artificial turf to allow for various activities and its parking lot would be redesigned.

City staff also recommended constructing a multi-use field and practice field at Parsons School, but placed the work at Davis and Kaiser as greater priorities.

The almost $10 million price tag for all three projects would be funded through $4.9 million slated for the originally intended work at Jack Hammett, with the rest coming from grants, park fees and other sources.

Mark Arblaster, president of the Newport Mesa Soccer Club, said the group spends around $3,000 each month to rent lights from Hertz for six months each year to play at Davis, in addition to thousands more to rent the fields.

"It's expensive, but we do it because we care about the kids. But we need help," Arblaster told the council.

Youth sports advocates have campaigned for years to have the fields lighted at night, particularly in the fall and winter months when the sun sets earlier in the day.

"This is just a huge, huge opportunity for us to bring the light so to speak to the community," said Costa Mesa United board member Brett Eckles. "This is a way to get those 10,000-plus Costa Mesa resident kids on fields throughout the year."

Once agreements with Newport-Mesa are in place, the city will move forward with public outreach efforts before bringing the matter to the Parks and Recreation Commission.
